item.title: Ipsum
item.description: Nullam et orci eu lorem consequat tincidunt vivamus et sagittis magna sed nunc rhoncus condimentum sem. In efficitur ligula tate urna. Maecenas massa sed magna lacinia magna pellentesque lorem ipsum dolor. Nullam et orci eu lorem consequat tincidunt. Vivamus et sagittis tempus.

item.title: Climate Change and Temperature Anomalies
item.description: To study climate change, we use: data on the Combined Land-Surface Air and Sea-Surface Water Temperature Anomalies in the Northern Hemisphere at NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies and the tabular data of temperature anomalies can be found here #we load this file using read_csv, skipping the first (redundant) row and coding NASAs NA's (***) as "na" weather <- read_csv("https://data.giss.nasa.gov/gistemp/tabledata_v3/NH.Ts+dSST.csv", skip = 1, na = "***") ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## Year = col_double(), ## Jan = col_double(), ## Feb = col_double(), ## Mar = col_double(), ## Apr = col_double(), ## May = col_double(), ## Jun = col_double(), ## Jul = col_double(), ## Aug = col_double(), ## Sep = col_double(), ## Oct = col_double(), ## Nov = col_double(), ## Dec = col_double(), ## `J-D` = col_double(), ## `D-N` = col_double(), ## DJF = col_double(), ## MAM = col_double(), ## JJA = col_double(), ## SON = col_double() ## ) #we inspect the dataframe's key variables and structure skim(weather) (#tab:inspecting_the_dataframe)Data summary Name weather Number of rows 140 Number of columns 19 _______________________ Column type frequency: numeric 19 ________________________ Group variables None Variable type: numeric

item.title: COVID-19 Death Rate Analysis for Different Demographics
item.description: #Let us revisit the [CDC Covid-19 Case Surveillance Data](https://data.cdc.gov/Case-Surveillance/COVID-19-Case-Surveillance-Public-Use-Data/vbim-akqf). There are well over 3 million entries of individual, de-identified patient data. Since this is a large file, I will use `vroom` to load it and you keep `cache=TRUE` in the chunk options. # URL link to CDC to download data url <- "https://data.cdc.gov/api/views/vbim-akqf/rows.csv?accessType=DOWNLOAD" covid_data <- vroom(url)%>% clean_names() ## Rows: 3,662,325 ## Columns: 11 ## Delimiter: "," ## chr [8]: current_status, sex, age_group, Race and ethnicity (combined), hosp_yn, icu_yn.

item.title: Four days in Copenhagen
item.description: Executive Summary Overview The purpose of this report is to explore data on AirBnB listings in Copenhagen and understand the key drivers of price variability, specifically focused on the price for a 4-night stay for 2 guests. The Problem What is the best model to predict overall price of AirBnB accommodation in Copenhagen for 2 people wishing to spend 4 nights in the city?

item.title: Mask Acceptance
item.description: NYT mask use Github source for data https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-data/tree/master/mask-use Getting the data url <- "https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-data/raw/master/mask-use/mask-use-by-county.csv" nyt_mask_survey <- read_csv(url) nyt_mask_survey <- nyt_mask_survey %>% clean_names() %>% mutate( mostly_yes= frequently+always, mostly_no = never+rarely, delta = mostly_yes-mostly_no ) glimpse(nyt_mask_survey) ## Rows: 3,142 ## Columns: 9 ## $ countyfp <chr> "01001", "01003", "01005", "01007", "01009", "01011", "010… ## $ never <dbl> 0.053, 0.083, 0.067, 0.020, 0.053, 0.031, 0.102, 0.152, 0.… ## $ rarely <dbl> 0.

item.title: Returns of Financial Stocks
item.description: library(tidyverse) # Load ggplot2, dplyr, and all the other tidyverse packages library(mosaic) library(ggthemes) library(lubridate) library(fivethirtyeight) library(hrbrthemes) library(here) library(skimr) library(janitor) library(vroom) library(tidyquant) library(kableExtra) library(ggrepel) library(patchwork) Here is the analysis on Returns of Financial Stock of a select few companies. We utilise the monthly, yearly and daily returns to gauge behaviour of these stock over a fixed period of time. # Read the dataset nyse <- read_csv(here::here("data","nyse.csv")) After loading the New York Stock Exchange Data, Let’s look at the distribution of companies within different sectors.
